The mansion, neglected during the war and the ensuing conflict between Netherlands and Indonesian Republican forces, recently became headquarters of the Dutch garrison of Buitenzorg, 30 miles south of Batavia.

caption_title: Uncle Sam's "Medicine" for Ailing Europe Lies Heaped on New Jersey Railroad Piers
Legend Says Yankee-Doodle Was Written on the Well Curb of Fort Crailo, Rensselaer
caption: During the French and Indian War a British Army surgeon is supposed to have composed the verses as he watched raw provincial militiamen drilling in motley garb. Later their sons proudly sang the derisive words as a marching song.

caption_title: At the Mouth of the Hudson Stands Miss Liberty, Holding Her Torch 300 Feet Aloft
caption: Some 170 steps lead visitors through her feet to the spiked crown; to perspiring parents conducting demanding offspring they seem endless. Gitt of the French people, the statue was shipped across the Atlantic in 1885.

caption_title: Fort Crailo, a Rensselaer Show Place, Preserves a Dutch Colonial Flavor
caption: An old record says: "The small stone fort was built at the order of the first Patroon as defense the hostile Mohicans." A cellar stone bears the inscription "1642."

caption_title: Saratoga Beauties, Obviously Not Healtli Seekers, Drink at a Medicinal Spring
caption: The springs' healthful qualities were known to Indians and wild animals long before white men began to exploit them in 1774. In mid-Victorian America Saratoga became the fashionable "Queen of the Spas."

caption_title: A Kandy Chief Glitters with Gold
caption: Gold gleams from his jacket of heavy brocade and enormous puffed sleeves. Staff and sword are of gold. Yards of silk wind around his waist in a sash and taper almost to his ankles. Kandy was an ancient capital of Ceylon. DUring the wars with the Portuguese and Dutch, before the days of British rule, nearly all of its buildings were burned except the temples and royal residence.

caption_title: A WAC Sergeant and Sinhalese Friends Compare Headgear
caption: American troops manning two airbases in Ceylon during World War II became well acquainted with the islanders. The 1310th Base Unit of the China-India-Burma Air Transport Corps operated one base as a way station on the route from India to Australia and the Philippines; the other was used as a shuttle point for tactical aircraft. Each had a 6,000-foot strip.

caption_title: Sinhalese, Tea Growers for a Century, Finally Learn to Drink It
caption: The British introduced tea growing to Ceylon in 1840. Now the island is the world's second largest producer of tea. Few of the islanders drank the beverage until recently, when it was popularized by mobile canteens such as this, which serve it by the cup in market places.

caption_title: Will I Look as Well 1,500 Years from Now?
caption: A Mesa Verde visitor calls on "Esther," one of the best preserved mummies ever found in the dry Southwest. Her skin is unbroken except for a small patch just below each knee. It is light brown in color with a warm reddish tone that could have been the young lady's actual complexion in life. The mummy weights 16 pounds, which represents Esther without her original moisture.

caption_title: Indian Folklore Is Sandoval Begay's Specialty
caption: This patriarch leads a group of Navajos in singing and dancing around a nightly campfire in Mesa Verde National Park. He also tends a cornfield on the mesa top near Cliff Palace and helps maintain the park grounds. Son of a famous old Navajo judge, Sandoval wears a bright gold shirt, yellow headbank, and turquoise necklace and earrings.

caption_title: Gazing from Lotty Mesa Top, Modern Man May lurn the Clock Back to Stone Age America
caption: Below the rock platform lies Navajo Canyon, one of many that seam Colorado's "Green table," or mesa verde in Spanish. From this point, near the edge of the Consolidated Ute Indian Reservation, many cave villages can be seen. Cliff Dwellers climbed to the flat top of the mesa to till their fields and hunt game.

caption_title: Parts of Four States Unfold in Verdant Panorama below Mesa Verde's Precipitous North Face
caption: Colorado, Utah, New Mexico, and Arizona meet a few miles from this spot. The road leading from the cliff ruins curves around the Knife Edge. Wild flowers are never picked except, as here, by naturalists for the park museum.

caption_title: Navajo Canyon's Overhanging Rim Forms a Massive Canopy for Square Tower House
caption: At least 125 Cilff Dwellers lived in this cave village of 60 rooms and eight kivas. On flat roofs, now missing, women ground corn and bent over cooking fires. Square Tower was built between 1204 and 1246 of our era.

caption_title: From Primitive Navajo Looms Come Bright-hued Blankets for Mesa Verde Visitors
caption: In a brush shelter before Spruce Tree Lodge, mother weaves while her daughters card and spin wool. Navajos are not related to the departed Cliff Dwellers. They come to Mesa Verde each summer from their reservation.

caption_title: Indians, Young and Old, Thrill to the Notes of a Street Musician's Sitar
caption: They halt outside a gaily decorated bazaar in Bund to hear a performance on this popular Indian stringed instrument. The modern mural at left shows how Rajputana has accepted the airplane without discarding the elephant.

caption_title: So Scarce Is Water that Housewives March a Mile and Back with Vessels of Brass or Clay on Their Heads
caption: Bound for a lake outside Jaisalmer, these women pass the National Geographic Society's photographic-survey car. Originally a United States Army ambulance, the car was bought by The Society from the Indian Government at a surplus war material storage yard in Calcutta. Mr. Wentzel converted it into a combination mobile headquarters, photographic supply house, and hotel! In it he has been traveling extensively for The Society across the length and breadth of India and Pakistan.

caption_title: A Trumpet Flourish Calls Jaipur, Rose-pink City, to the Gangor Festival
caption: Centuries-old tradition is observed in the annual rite. held in honor of Gauri, the goddess of abundance. Crack Camel Corpsmen have a place of honor in the elaborate procession which will pass along paved streets 111 feet wide. The city's main avenues. laid out with mathematical precision, are flanked by palaces of Oriental fantasy. Houses. towers, and temples all are of one color-rose.

caption_title: Cattle, Monotonously Treading a Ramp, Raise Well Water to Irrigate the Parched Fields of Ajmer-Merwara Province
caption: This primitive system satisfies the country's needs; efficient motor pumps might drain the underground reserves.

caption_title: Tigers and Elephants Brighten the Community House of the City Sweepers, Who Dwell as a Caste Apart
caption: At the noon hour women gather on the balcony, men swap stories, and pigs glean the yard. In modern Bundi, outside the old walls, broad avenues are flanked with Government office buildings, a public park, the big State Hotel, a hospital, and a new motion-picture theater.

caption_title: Whirling Skirts Balloon Like Doughnuts as Póvoa Folk Perform a Ballet on the Sand
caption: Lighthearted Portuguese, with gay costumes and melancholy ballads, strive to preserve the simple life in the machine age. The vira, illustrated here, is a quadrilateral dance executed by two boys and two girls.

caption_title: Shouts and Odors Assault the Atmosphere in Pôrto Market. Visitors Run a Fishwives' Noisy Gantlet
caption: Look at these faces. They are a compound of Celtic Iberians, invading Phoenicians, Visigoths, and others. In the south, Moorish strains appear. Imperial Rome called its Portuguese colony Lusitania and gave the people their language.

caption_title: To Tighten a Drum, Build a Fire and Heat the Drumhead
caption: At Carnival time mummers roam Montevideo's streets, dancing for coins to the offbeat rhythm of drums. Lacking drawstrings or other stretching devices, they heat their drumheads over paper fires to raise the tone.

caption_title: Uruguay's Classic Capitol Rises at the End of a Broad Montevideo Avenue
caption: Avenida Agraciada has recently been widened and beautified. Big banks and office buildings have made it their home. The second building to the right houses the American Embassy and consulate. Traffic, which few years ago went to the left, now runs to the right.

caption_title: Uruguayan Trenchermen Never Slice Off More than They Can Chew
caption: Old-time gauchos ate barbecued beef by grasping a hunk in the teeth and cutting away all but a bite. The sharp facon, or belt knife, served them in combat as well as at dinner. Connoisseurs prize whole beef roasted in the hairy hide, for the juices are sealed in. This descendant of gauchos works on a cattle ranch near Artigas. His sure hand has never nicked his nose.
